summary: This study assessed the external validity of aspirin randomized clinical trials (RCTs) for primary prevention of cardiovascular disease by applying eligibility criteria from 14 guideline-cited RCTs to a real-world dataset of adults aged ≥40 years without CVD. Eligibility proportions and differences in cardiovascular events, major bleeding, and non-cardiovascular mortality were analyzed. Among 570,211 patients, the median proportion ineligible for each RCT was 90.7%, indicating limited applicability of trial evidence to real-world populations.

This study evaluated the efficacy and safety of glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists (GLP-1RAs) in improving histologic features of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH) compared with placebo. Primary outcomes were MASH resolution without worsening fibrosis and at least one-stage fibrosis improvement at 12–18 months. Secondary outcomes included changes in fibrosis stage, disease activity scores, liver histology, and serious adverse events.

This cross-sectional study investigated the association between diet quality, measured by the Healthy Eating Index-2015, and kidney function in 8,787 Iranian adults aged 35–65 years from the RaNCD cohort. Dietary intake was assessed using a food frequency questionnaire, and kidney function was estimated using glomerular filtration rate calculated by the MDRD equation.

This prospective, open-label randomized controlled trial evaluated the effectiveness of a real-time continuous glucose monitoring system in 172 patients with type 2 diabetes from a single center in Milan. Participants were randomized into two groups and followed for six months. The trial is registered under NCT07089979.

This study evaluated the accuracy of phosphatidylethanol (PEth) as a biomarker for detecting heavy drinking in individuals with alcohol use disorder. Data from a 26-week randomized placebo-controlled trial of 127 participants were analyzed. PEth levels were compared with self-reported alcohol consumption, and correlations were assessed over multiple time windows to determine optimal cutoff values using ROC analysis.

This study reports long-term outcomes from the FAME 2 trial comparing fractional flow reserve–guided percutaneous coronary intervention plus medical therapy versus medical therapy alone in patients with stable coronary artery disease. Among 748 patients followed long term, FFR-guided PCI reduced the composite outcome of death, myocardial infarction, or urgent revascularization, primarily due to fewer urgent revascularizations.

This review describes the role of sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors in the management of heart failure with reduced and preserved ejection fraction. Evidence from randomized trials shows reductions in hospitalization and cardiovascular mortality, including in non-diabetic patients. The mechanisms and clinical considerations for combining SGLT2 inhibitors with diuretics are discussed.

This prospective observational study evaluated doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity in newly diagnosed breast cancer patients with type 2 diabetes receiving dapagliflozin in addition to metformin. Sixty patients were enrolled and assessed using echocardiographic methods to examine potential cardioprotective effects of dapagliflozin during chemotherapy.

This randomized controlled trial examined risk factors for falls in older adults with major depressive disorder receiving antidepressant treatment, including bupropion augmentation. Falls reported during biweekly visits over approximately ten weeks were analyzed. Fall risk was associated with prior fall history, burden of physical illness, and reduced physical function.

This retrospective study evaluated adherence to guideline-directed medical therapy and outcomes in 431 patients with heart failure, coronary artery disease, and type 2 diabetes presenting with acute coronary syndrome. Medication adherence was assessed before and after ACS over 36 months. Primary outcomes were rehospitalization and all-cause mortality.

This animal study investigated region-specific dopaminergic alterations in the hippocampus, striatum, and prefrontal cortex of streptozotocin-induced diabetic mice. Behavioral testing and gene expression analysis were performed to examine associations between diabetes, dopaminergic dysfunction, and social behavioral deficits.

This prospective multicenter study evaluated the association between pullback pressure gradient (PPG), a physiological index of coronary disease pattern, and residual angina at one year. Patients with fractional flow reserve ≤0.80 were enrolled, and angina-related outcomes were assessed using the Seattle Angina Questionnaire.

This double-blind randomized trial examined the effects of lorcaserin on body weight, body composition, lipidomic profiles, and muscle-regulating hormones in 48 adults with obesity over six months. Changes were analyzed using mixed models and multivariate lipidomic analyses.

This review summarizes evidence linking influenza infection to increased cardiovascular complications, including acute coronary syndromes and heart failure, particularly in older and high-risk populations. Randomized trials and meta-analyses show that influenza vaccination is associated with significant reductions in major adverse cardiovascular events and mortality.

This four-arm randomized study evaluated the effects of yoga, gastro-hepatic pack therapy, their combination, and standard care on glycemic control and psychological stress in 120 adults with type 2 diabetes. Glycemic parameters and stress scores were measured before and after intervention, with reductions observed across intervention groups.

This substudy of the GRADE trial examined medication adherence among 1,739 patients with type 2 diabetes randomized to different add-on therapies to metformin. Adherence was measured semiannually over three years and analyzed in relation to glycemic outcomes.

This randomized, double-blind clinical trial evaluated whether endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with minor papillotomy reduces pancreatitis outcomes in patients with pancreas divisum. A total of 148 participants were enrolled across referral centers in the United States and Canada, with chronic pancreatitis as a primary outcome.

This Bayesian network meta-analysis compared six treatment regimens for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction involving SGLT2 inhibitors, angiotensin receptor–neprilysin inhibitors, and conventional therapies. Outcomes included cardiovascular death or hospitalization, mortality, functional measures, biomarkers, and adverse events.
